Arsenic occurs in many minerals, usually in combination with [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur) and [metals](/wiki/Metal), but also as a pure elemental [crystal](/wiki/Crystal). Arsenic is a [metalloid](/wiki/Metalloid). It has various [allotropes](/wiki/Allotropy), but only the grey form, which has a metallic appearance, is important to industry. The primary use of arsenic is in alloys of [lead](/wiki/Lead) (for example, in [car batteries](/wiki/Car_batteries) and [ammunition](/wiki/Ammunition)). Arsenic is a common n-type [dopant](/wiki/Dopant) in [semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor) electronic devices. It is also of the III-V [compound semiconductor](/wiki/Compound_semiconductor) [gallium arsenide](/wiki/Gallium_arsenide). Arsenic and its compounds, especially the trioxide, are used in the production of [pesticides](/wiki/Pesticide), treated wood products, [herbicides](/wiki/Herbicide), and [insecticides](/wiki/Insecticide). These applications are declining with the increasing recognition of the toxicity of arsenic and its compounds. [[9]](#cite_note-Ullmann-9) [A few species of bacteria](#Bacteria) are able to use arsenic compounds as respiratory [metabolites](/wiki/Metabolite). Trace quantities of arsenic are an essential [dietary element](/wiki/Mineral_(nutrient)) in rats, hamsters, goats, chickens, and presumably other species. A role in human metabolism is not known. As a result, the [adsorption](/wiki/Adsorption) of arsenic is reduced and dissolved arsenic accumulates in groundwater. These metabolic interferences lead to death from multi-system [organ failure](/wiki/Organ_failure).
